awd_titl_txt: GOALI: Transforming Wavefronts with Additive Manufactured Electromagnetic Metasurfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
Part 1
A new approach to controlling electromagnetic waves is proposed using finely textured surfaces (metasurfaces) fabricated through advanced additive manufacturing. Unlike conventional curved lenses that simply phase correct and focus waves, the proposed metasurfaces can transform both the phase and amplitude of electromagnetic waves. Today, such functionality requires complex assemblies of lenses (compound lenses) that are often bulky and cost prohibitive.  The advance-manufactured metasurfaces promise to extend functionality, reduce size and weight, as well as lower manufacturing costs over these existing lens-based solutions. The proposed, finely-textured surfaces (metasurfaces) will enable ultra-thin, low cost and highly efficient antennas for airborne satellite communications and imaging, as well as make possible low-cost, low-power imaging and radar solutions with applications to environmental remote sensing, autonomous vehicle navigation and security scanners. The proposed metasurfaces promise to separate electromagnetic functionality from shape. Conventional lenses derive their electromagnetic properties from their shape. The proposed surfaces can take on arbitrary shapes while performing a targeted functionality, since they derive their properties from their fine texture. This will enable them to be seamlessly integrated into various form factors.

This collaborative University-Industry effort supports advanced manufacturing in America.  Specifically, the proposed research will advance additive manufacturing methods through the development of affordable, advanced-manufactured electromagnetic devices.  An integral component of this project is education and outreach.  It includes internships for graduate students with the industry partner, summer undergraduate research projects at the University of Michigan, as well as the development of a short course and graduate course material in electromagnetic metamaterials and additive manufacturing by the University PI and Industry co-PI. The outreach effort will also include the organization of joint technical sessions at prominent conferences with both academic and industrial invitees.

Part 2
The objective of this University-Industry research effort is to develop reflectionless metasurfaces capable of transforming an impinging electromagnetic wavefront, in both phase and amplitude, to a desired aperture field.   Unlike conventional, curved lenses that simply phase correct wavefronts, the proposed metasurfaces can apply extreme phase, polarization, and amplitude changes to a wavefront in a low-loss manner. Additive manufacturing capabilities of the industry partner will be advanced, and exploited to realize the proposed metasurfaces that require both in-plane and out-of-plane structure. Unlike the metasurfaces reported to date that offer only polarization and phase control, the proposed metasurfaces will also be able to manipulate the amplitude distribution of a wavefront. A theoretical framework and systematic approach to designing such metasurfaces is proposed. The metasurfaces will possess both tangential and normal (out-of-plane) surface parameters that can be electric, magnetic, and magneto-electric. The complex geometries required to achieve these surface parameters will be fabricated through advanced additive manufacturing methods developed by industry partner. The additive manufacturing methods allow both low-loss dielectrics and high conductivity metals to be seamlessly combined into three-dimensional geometries. 

Controlling the polarization, phase and amplitude of electromagnetic waves is critical to electromagnetic systems ranging from RF to optical wavelengths. The proposed metasurfaces will enable ultra-thin microwave, millimeter-wave and sub-millimeter-wave lenses that can generate wavefronts with arbitrary amplitude, polarization, and phase profiles. Applications will range from optimal antenna-feed coupling, lenses that allow precise control over the radiated beam pointing direction and sidelobe level, to the formation of perfect holograms with images reconstructed in both phase and amplitude. Several business units of the industry partner will benefit from the extended functionality, reduced size and weight, and potentially lower manufacturing cost of these metasurfaces that are enabled by additive manufacturing.

por.por_cntn:
There is an increasing demand for compact electromagnetic devices that are multi-functional or demonstrate multi-input multi-output functionality. The emergence of metamaterial engineering in the past few decades has provided a promising route to realize electromagnetic devices with such stringent specifications. Metamaterials are artificially engineered materials with unusual material properties that are not readily available in nature. Metamaterials derive their properties from subwavelength textures in the material which represent constituent elements of the metamaterials, much like molecules represent constituent elements of media such as air, silicon, and so on. Therefore, the evolution of fabrication technology in the late 20th and early 21st centuries is key to the progress made in metamaterial engineering.

The major goals of this project have been to extend the current state of the art in the design of metamaterial devices to allow unprecedented control over the phase, amplitude, and polarization of an incident electromagnetic (EM) wave and therefore, develop methods to design EM devices with arbitrarily complex functionality. Additionally, metamaterial devices offer large degrees of freedom, therefore, optimization-based approaches are introduced to find non-analytical, non-intuitive solutions to increasingly stringent constraints. Initial work was devoted to developing methods to design and simulate 2-D omega media, (having a polarization-preserving magneto-electric response), using 2-D circuit networks or transmission-line metamaterials. This work extended the range of achievable material parameters of circuit-based metamaterials and revealed their potential in providing phase and power control of electromagnetic waves and ultimately leading to a journal paper entitled “L. Szymanski and A. Grbic, in 2019 IEEE International Symposium on Antennas and Propagation and USNC-URSI Radio Science Meeting (IEEE, Atlanta, GA, USA, 2019), pp. 1201–1202”.

Subsequently, an optimization-based inverse design tool was developed that coupled a custom circuit solver with an optimizer to develop inhomogeneous, anisotropic metamaterials. This approach enabled the design of large, inhomogeneous metamaterials which provide large degrees of freedom. It also identified non-intuitive solutions, which analytical approaches fail to do. In parallel, the research effort pursued the development of all-dielectric polarization control devices using additive manufacturing techniques, which produce broadband, multiband, or multifunctional devices that are low-loss and reflectionless. Physical prototypes of isotropic polarization rotator (rotates incident wave polarization by 90 degrees at 35 GHz) and dual-band linear to circular polarization converter (application in satellite downlink ~19 GHz and uplink ~29 GHz) devices were designed and fabricated.

The computational inverse design procedure was improved by incorporating the adjoint variable method. This further reduced the time and computational resources required to design devices with large numbers of design variables. The uniqueness of this approach lies in the significant time reduction associated with using a circuit solver and reduced-order modeling to compute the forward problem. To demonstrate the capability of this method, guided-wave devices for antenna beamforming and analog signal processing were designed and fabricated. The results for this work have been disseminated in papers entitled “L. Szymanski, G. Gok, and A. Grbic, IEEE Trans. Antennas Propagat. 70, 3495 (2022)” and “L. Szymanski, G. Gok, and A. Grbic, IEEE Antennas Propag. Mag. 64, 63 (2022)” confirming the design approach can produce practical devices. Further, an antenna beamformer that exhibits negative refraction was designed and manufactured to show the extreme phase transformations that can be achieved using this design approach.

The development of the inverse design approach initiated an interest in developing electromagnetic devices with complex three-dimensional unit cells. Key progress has been made on extracting effective material parameters of complex three-dimensional sub-wavelength unit cell topologies on a separate research project. By mapping the material parameter distributions derived using the inverse design procedure to the aforementioned unit cells, three-dimensional metamaterials have been developed. Close agreement has been observed between the performance of homogenized (circuit theory solution) and three-dimensional structures (commercial Finite Element Method solution).

Furthermore, initial work was performed on extending the inverse design procedure to inhomogeneous anisotropic metamaterials consisting of perfectly-matched unit cells, hereafter called perfectly matched metamaterials (PMM). This has enabled the design of metamaterials that are devoid of inter-cell reflections, and therefore rely on refractive effects to achieve arbitrarily complex electromagnetic functions. This promises compact electromagnetic devices that have low loss and broadband operation. This work is reported in a conference paper that has been accepted for presentation.
